title: 104_hr2532
content:
The Family Farm Empowerment Act of 1995 includes provisions for marketing loans, total acreage base system, amendments to price support programs, elimination of acreage reduction programs, extension of export programs, suspension of permanent price support authority, and removal of certain rules. The Family Farm Empowerment Act of 1995 includes provisions for marketing loans for certain agricultural commodities from 1996 through 2002. The Family Farm Empowerment Act of 1995 provides marketing loans for covered commodities such as rice, upland cotton, feed grains, wheat, and oilseeds. The loans have a 15-month term and are available to eligible producers from 1996 through 2002. Eligible producers for marketing loans must not exceed total acreage base of the farm. Loans are at 115% of the average national price. Total loans per producer cannot exceed $175,000. Repayment terms apply. Producers on a farm may repay marketing loans for covered commodities at a rate determined by the loan rate or the prevailing domestic market price set by the Secretary. The Secretary will establish a formula to determine the market price for each commodity and announce it periodically. The Secretary will establish an Adjustment Account to make payments to producers participating in the marketing loan program for covered commodities. Payments will also be made to producers of previous crops authorized under specific sections but not yet paid. The Adjustment Account will provide necessary funds for marketing loans under subsection (b) and remain available until expended. Producers can request an advance payment of up to 10% of the projected marketing loan before planting. The Secretary may make payments to producers who agree to forego obtaining marketing loans for covered commodities from 1996 to 2002. Producers can receive payments under this subsection by forgoing marketing loans for covered commodities. Payment is calculated by multiplying the loan payment rate by the quantity of the commodity foregone. The loan payment rate is the difference between the loan rate and the repayment rate for the commodity. SEC. 3. TOTAL ACREAGE BASE SYSTEM. (a) Definitions.--Section 502 of the Agricultural Act of 1949 is amended to define 'feed grains' as corn, grain sorghums, barley, oats, and rye, and 'covered commodity' as rice, upland cotton, feed grains, wheat, or oilseeds. 
(b) Crop Acreage Base.--Section 503 of the Act is amended to establish and maintain a total crop acreage base for covered commodities, including those produced under double cropping practices. The amendment includes changes to the calculation of the total crop acreage base for covered commodities, removing subsections (b) and (g), and revising subsection (h) of the Agricultural Act of 1949. The amendment revises the Agricultural Act of 1949 by updating the crops of covered commodities from 1991 through 1997 to 1991 through 2002. The amendment updates the covered commodities in the Agricultural Act of 1949 from 1991-1997 to 1991-2002. It includes conforming amendments to current price support programs for program crops. The Agricultural Act of 1949 is amended to update the covered commodities from 1991-1997 to 1991-2002. This includes adjustments to price support programs for wheat, feed grains, and cotton, changing the end year from 1997 to 1995. The Agricultural Act of 1949 is amended to update covered commodities from 1991-1997 to 1991-2002, including adjustments to price support programs for wheat, feed grains, and cotton. Amendments involve changing the end year from 1997 to 1995 for various subsections and programs. Amendments are made to the Agricultural Act of 1949, updating covered commodities from 1991-1997 to 1991-2002. Changes include adjusting price support programs for wheat, feed grains, and cotton by shifting the end year from 1997 to 1995 in various subsections and programs. SEC. 5. ELIMINATION OF ACREAGE REDUCTION PROGRAMS. Amendments to the Agricultural Act of 1949 involve removing acreage reduction programs for wheat, feed grains, cotton, and rice by redesignating subsections. SEC. 6. EXTENSION OF COTTONSEED OIL AND SUNFLOWER OIL EXPORT PROGRAMS. SEC. 6 extends cottonseed oil and sunflower oil export programs through 2002. SEC. 7 suspends permanent price support authority. During the period June 1, 1995, through May 31, 2003, wheat processors and exporters are exempt from certain certificate requirements under the Agricultural Adjustment Act of 1938. Additionally, provisions related to land use, wheat marketing allocation, and producer certificates are suspended for the 1996 through 2002 wheat crops. Certain quota provisions under a joint resolution from 1941 are also suspended. During 1996-2002, certain sections of the Agricultural Act of 1949 regarding wheat, feed grains, and oilseeds are not applicable. This includes provisions related to crop planting and loan programs. Amendment to the Agricultural Act of 1949 removes provisions related to oilseeds. SEC. 8. REMOVAL OF THREE-ENTITY RULE; DIRECT ATTRIBUTION. Amendment to the Food Security Act of 1985 regarding direct attribution of payments received by individuals and entities.
